2128    /**
2129     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2130     *  in the given String with values from the given maps. The method will
2131     *  try the maps in the given sequence.<br>
2132     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2133     *  replaced at all.<br>
2134     *  <br>If a value from one of the maps contains a variable itself, this
2135     *  will not be replaced.<br>
2136     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2137     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2138     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2139     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2140     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2141     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2142     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2143     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2144     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2145     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2146     *  special variable.
2147     *
2148     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2149     *  @param  sources The maps with the replacement values.
2150     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2151     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2152     *
2153     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2154     *
2155     *  @since 0.0.5
2156     *  @deprecated Use
2157     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Map[])}
2158     *      instead.
2159     */
2160    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
2161    @SafeVarargs
2162    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2163    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2164    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Map<String,? extends Object>... sources )
2165    {
2166        return Template.replaceVariable( text, sources );
2167    }   //  replaceVariable()
2168
2169    /**
2170     *  Replaces the variables of the form <code>${&lt;<i>name</i>&gt;}</code>
2171     *  in the given String with values returned by the given retriever
2172     *  function for the variable name.<br>
2173     *  <br>If no replacement value could be found, the variable will not be
2174     *  replaced at all.<br>
2175     *  <br>If the retriever function returns a value that contains a variable
2176     *  itself, this will not be replaced.<br>
2177     *  <br>The retriever function will be called only once for each variable
2178     *  name; if the text contains the same variable multiple times, it will
2179     *  always be replaced with the same value.<br>
2180     *  <br>The variables names are case-sensitive.<br>
2181     *  <br>Valid variable name may not contain other characters than the
2182     *  letters from 'a' to 'z' (upper case and lower case), the digits from
2183     *  '0' to '9' and the special characters underscore ('_') and dot ('.'),
2184     *  after an optional prefix character.<br>
2185     *  <br>Allowed prefixes are the tilde ('~'), the slash ('/'), the equal
2186     *  sign ('='), the colon (':'), the percent sign ('%'), and the ampersand
2187     *  ('&amp;').<br>
2188     *  <br>The prefix character is part of the name.<br>
2189     *  <br>Finally, there is the single underscore that is allowed as a
2190     *  special variable.
2191     *
2192     *  @param  text    The text with the variables; may be {@code null}.
2193     *  @param  retriever   The function that will retrieve the replacement
2194     *      values for the given variable names.
2195     *  @return The new text, or {@code null} if the provided value for
2196     *      {@code text} was already {@code null}.
2197     *
2198     *  @see #VARIABLE_PATTERN
2199     *
2200     *  @since 0.0.5
2201     *  @deprecated Use
2202     *      {@link Template#replaceVariable(CharSequence, Function)}
2203     *      instead.
2204     */
2205    @SuppressWarnings( "DeprecatedIsStillUsed" )
2206    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2207    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2208    public static final String replaceVariable( final CharSequence text, final Function<? super String, Optional<String>> retriever )
2209    {
2210        return Template.replaceVariable( text, retriever );
2211    }   //  replaceVariable()
2212
2213    /**
2214     *  Splits a String by the given separator character and returns an array
2215     *  of all parts. In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2216     *  another separator char, an empty String will be place to the array.
2217     *  Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if the
2218     *  first character of the String is a separator, the returned array will
2219     *  start with an empty string, as it will end with an empty String if the
2220     *  last character is a separator.<br>
2221     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2222     *  containing just the empty String.
2223     *
2224     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2225     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2226     *  @return The parts of the String.
2227     *
2228     *  @since 0.0.5
2229     */
2230    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2231    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final char separator )
2232    {
2233        return splitString( string, (int) separator );
2234    }   //  splitString()
2235
2236    /**
2237     *  Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
2238     *  Unicode code point, and returns an array of all parts. In case a
2239     *  separator character is immediately followed by another separator char,
2240     *  an empty String will be placed to the array. Beginning and end of the
2241     *  String are treated as separators, so if the first character of the
2242     *  String is a separator, the returned array will start with an empty
2243     *  String, as it will end with an empty String if the last character is a
2244     *  separator.<br>
2245     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2246     *  containing just the empty String.
2247     *
2248     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2249     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2250     *  @return The parts of the String.
2251     *
2252     *  @since 0.0.5
2253     */
2254    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2255    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final int separator )
2256    {
2257        final var retValue = stream( string, separator ).toArray( String []::new );
2258
2259        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2260        return retValue;
2261    }   //  splitString()
2262
2263    /**
2264     *  Splits a String by the given separator sequence and returns an array
2265     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2266     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be placed to the
2267     *  array. Beginning and end of the String are treated as separators, so if
2268     *  the first part of the String equals the separator sequence, the
2269     *  returned array will start with an empty String, as it will end with an
2270     *  empty string if the last part would equal the separator sequence..<br>
2271     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be an array
2272     *  containing just the empty String.
2273     *
2274     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2275     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
2276     *  @return The parts of the String.
2277     *
2278     *  @since 0.0.5
2279     */
2280    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2281    public static final String [] splitString( final CharSequence string, final CharSequence separator )
2282    {
2283        final var retValue = stream( string, separator).toArray( String []::new );
2284
2285        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2286        return retValue;
2287    }   //  splitString()
2288
2289    /**
2290     *  Splits a String by the given separator character and returns a
2291     *  {@link Stream}
2292     *  of all parts. In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2293     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
2294     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2295     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
2296     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
2297     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.<br>
2298     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2299     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2300     *
2301     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2302     *  @param  separator   The separator character.
2303     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2304     *
2305     *  @since 0.0.7
2306     */
2307    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2308    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final char separator )
2309    {
2310        return stream( string, (int) separator );
2311    }   //  stream()
2312
2313    /**
2314     *  Splits a String by the given separator character, identified by its
2315     *  Unicode code point, and returns a
2316     *  {@link Stream}
2317     *  of all parts. In case a separator character is immediately followed by
2318     *  another separator char, an empty String will be put to the
2319     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2320     *  separators, so if the first character of the String is a separator, the
2321     *  returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty String, as it will end
2322     *  with an empty String if the last character is a separator.<br>
2323     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2324     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2325     *
2326     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2327     *  @param  separator   The code point for the separator character.
2328     *  @return A {@code Stream} instance with the parts of the String.
2329     *
2330     *  @since 0.0.7
2331     */
2332    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2333    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final int separator )
2334    {
2335        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2336        final var s = requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ).codePoints().toArray();
2337        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2338        var begin = -1;
2339        for( var i = 0 ; i < s.length; ++i )
2340        {
2341            if( begin == -1 )
2342            {
2343                begin = i;
2344            }
2345            if( s [ i ] == separator )
2346            {
2347                builder.add( new String( s, begin, i - begin ).intern() );
2348                begin = -1;
2349            }
2350        }
2351
2352        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2353        if( (begin >= 0) && (begin < s.length) )
2354        {
2355            builder.add( new String( s, begin, s.length - begin ).intern() );
2356        }
2357        if( (s.length == 0) || (s [s.length - 1] == separator) )
2358        {
2359            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2360        }
2361
2362        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2363        final var retValue = builder.build();
2364
2365        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2366        return retValue;
2367    }   //  stream()
2368
2369    /**
2370     *  Splits a String by the given separator sequence and returns a
2371     *  {@link Stream}
2372     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2373     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to the
2374     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2375     *  separators, so if the first part of the String equals the separator
2376     *  sequence, the returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty string,
2377     *  as it will end with an empty String if the last part would equal the
2378     *  separator sequence.<br>
2379     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2380     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2381     *
2382     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2383     *  @param  separator   The separator sequence.
2384     *  @return The parts of the String.
2385     *
2386     *  @since 0.0.7
2387     */
2388    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2389    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final CharSequence separator )
2390    {
2391        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2392        var s = requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ).toString();
2393        final var t = requireNotEmptyArgument( separator, "separator" ).toString();
2394
2395        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2396        var pos = Integer.MAX_VALUE;
2397        while( isNotEmpty( s ) && (pos >= 0) )
2398        {
2399            pos = s.indexOf( t );
2400            ResultHandlerSwitch: switch( Integer.signum( pos ) )
2401            {
2402                case 0: /* String starts with separator */
2403                {
2404                    builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2405                    s = s.substring( t.length() );
2406                    break ResultHandlerSwitch;
2407                }
2408
2409                case 1: /* String contains a separator somewhere */
2410                {
2411                    builder.add( s.substring( 0, pos ) );
2412                    s = s.substring( pos + t.length() );
2413                    break ResultHandlerSwitch;
2414                }
2415
2416                case -1: /* Just leave the loop */
2417                default: break ResultHandlerSwitch;
2418            }   //  ResultHandlerSwitch:
2419        }
2420
2421        //---* Add the rest *--------------------------------------------------
2422        builder.add( s );
2423
2424        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2425        final var retValue = builder.build();
2426
2427        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2428        return retValue;
2429    }   //  stream()
2430
2431    /**
2432     *  Splits a String using the given regular expression and returns a
2433     *  {@link Stream}
2434     *  of all parts. In case a separator sequence is immediately followed by
2435     *  another separator sequence, an empty String will be put to the
2436     *  {@code Stream}. Beginning and end of the String are treated as
2437     *  separators, so if the first part of the String equals the separator
2438     *  sequence, the returned {@code Stream} will start with an empty string,
2439     *  as it will end with an empty String if the last part would equal the
2440     *  separator sequence.<br>
2441     *  <br>In case the String is empty, the return value will be a
2442     *  {@code Stream} containing just the empty String.
2443     *
2444     *  @note This method behaves different from
2445     *      {@link String#split(String)}
2446     *      as it will return trailing empty Strings.
2447     *
2448     *  @param  string  The String to split.
2449     *  @param  pattern The separator sequence.
2450     *  @return The parts of the String.
2451     *
2452     *  @see String#split(String)
2453     *  @see Pattern#split(CharSequence)
2454     *
2455     *  @since 0.0.7
2456     */
2457    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.7" )
2458    public static final Stream<String> stream( final CharSequence string, final Pattern pattern )
2459    {
2460        requireNonNullArgument( pattern, "pattern" );
2461
2462        //---* Process the string *--------------------------------------------
2463        final var builder = Stream.<String>builder();
2464        if( isEmpty( requireNonNullArgument( string, "string" ) ) )
2465        {
2466            builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2467        }
2468        else
2469        {
2470            final var parts = pattern.split( string );
2471            for( final var part : parts )
2472            {
2473                builder.add( part );
2474            }
2475            final var matcher = pattern.matcher( string );
2476            var count = 0;
2477            while( matcher.find() ) ++count;
2478            //noinspection ForLoopWithMissingComponent
2479            for( ; count >= parts.length; --count )
2480            {
2481                builder.add( EMPTY_STRING );
2482            }
2483        }
2484
2485        //---* Create the return value *---------------------------------------
2486        final var retValue = builder.build();
2487
2488        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2489        return retValue;
2490    }   //  stream()
2491
2492    /**
2493     *  Strips HTML or XML tags from the given String, without touching other
2494     *  entities (like {@code &amp;} or {@code &nbsp;}). The result would be
2495     *  the effective text, stripped from all other whitespace (except single
2496     *  blanks).<br>
2497     *  <br>This means that the result for
2498     *  <pre><code>stripTags( &quot;&lt;html&gt;
2499     *      &lt;head&gt;
2500     *        &hellip;
2501     *      &lt;/head&gt;
2502     *      &lt;body&gt;
2503     *        &lt;a href='&hellip;'&gt;       Simple          &lt;br&gt;
2504     *          &lt;br&gt;           Text       &lt;/a&gt;
2505     *      &lt;/body&gt;
2506     *  &lt;/html&gt;&quot; )</code></pre> would be just
2507     *  &quot;{@code Simple Text}&quot;.<br>
2508     *  <br>Comments will be stripped as well, and {@code <pre>} tags are not
2509     *  interpreted, with the consequence that any formatting with whitespace
2510     *  gets lost. {@code CDATA} elements are stripped, too.
2511     *
2512     *  @param  s   The HTML/XML string.
2513     *  @return The string without the tags.
2514     *
2515     *  @since 0.0.7
2516     */
2517    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2518    public static final String stripTags( final CharSequence s )
2519    {
2520        final var retValue = new StringBuilder();
2521        if( isNotEmptyOrBlank( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) ) )
2522        {
2523            final var matcher = m_TagRemovalPattern.matcher( s );
2524            final var buffer = matcher.replaceAll( " " ).trim().codePoints().toArray();
2525            int lastChar = NULL_CHAR;
2526            ScanLoop: for( final var c : buffer )
2527            {
2528                if( isWhitespace( c ) )
2529                {
2530                    //---* Consecutive whitespace detected *-------------------
2531                    if( isWhitespace( lastChar ) ) continue ScanLoop;
2532
2533                    //---* All resulting whitespace have to be blanks *--------
2534                    retValue.append( " " );
2535                }
2536                else
2537                {
2538                    //---* Write the character *-------------------------------
2539                    retValue.append( toChars( c ) );
2540                }
2541                lastChar = c;
2542            }   //  ScanLoop:
2543        }
2544
2545        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2546        return retValue.toString();
2547    }   //  stripTags()
2548
2549    /**
2550     *  Strips characters from the given input that are not allowed (or should
2551     *  be at least avoided) for a file or folder name on most or all operating
2552     *  systems.<br>
2553     *  <br>The following characters will be stripped:
2554     *  <dl>
2555     *  <dt><b>:</b> (colon)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used to separate
2556     *  the drive letter from the path and file name; on Unix-like operating
2557     *  systems it would be valid, but it can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2558     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on that operating systems.</dd>
2559     *  <dt><b>\</b> (backslash)</dt><dd>On Windows systems it is used as the
2560     *  path separator, while on Unix-like operating systems it is problematic
2561     *  in other ways. For example, it is used to escape blanks in not-quoted
2562     *  file or folder names.</dd>
2563     *  <dt><b>/</b> (slash or forward slash)</dt><dd>The path separator on
2564     *  Unix-like operating systems, but Java will use it that way on Windows
2565     *  systems, too.</dd>
2566     *  <dt><b>;</b> (semicolon)</dt><dd>It can cause issues on the {@code PATH}
2567     *  and {@code CLASSPATH} variables on Windows.</dd>
2568     *  <dt><b>*</b> (asterisk)</dt><dd>The asterisk is often used as wild card
2569     *  character in shell programs to find groups of files; using it in a file
2570     *  name can cause funny effects.</dd>
2571     *  <dt><b>?</b> (question mark)</dt><dd>The question mark is used on
2572     *  Windows as a wild card for a single character; similar to the asterisk,
2573     *  it can cause funny effects when used in a file name.</dd>
2574     *  <dt><b>&quot;</b> (double quotes)</dt>
2575     *  <dt><b>'</b> (single quotes)</dt><dd>Both have some potential to
2576     *  confuse the various shell programs of all operating systems.</dd>
2577     *  <dt><b>@</b> ('at'-sign)</dt><dd>Although it is allowed for file and
2578     *  folder names, it causes issues when used in the URL for that respective
2579     *  file.</dd>
2580     *  <dt><b>|</b> (pipe symbol)</dt><dd>Similar to the '*' (asterisk), the
2581     *  pipe-symbol has â as the name already indicates - a meaning on most
2582     *  shells that would make it difficult to manage files that contains this
2583     *  character in their names.</dd>
2584     *  <dt><b>&lt;</b> (less than)</dt>
2585     *  <dt><b>&gt;</b> (greater than)</dt><dd>Like the pipe, these two have a
2586     *  meaning on most shells that would make it difficult to manage files
2587     *  that contains one of these characters in their names.</dd>
2588     *  <dt>Whitespace</dt><dd>Only blanks will remain, any other whitespace
2589     *  characters are stripped.</dd>
2590     *  </dl>
2591     *  Finally, the method will strip all leading and trailing blanks;
2592     *  although blanks are usually allowed, they are confusing when not
2593     *  surrounded by some visible characters.
2594     *  Especially regarding the characters that are critical for shells ('*',
2595     *  '?', '&quot;', ''', '|', '&lt;', and '&gt;') this method is
2596     *  over-cautious, as most shells could handle them after proper escaping
2597     *  the offending characters or quoting the file name.<br>
2598     *  <br>This method furthermore assumes that any other Unicode character is
2599     *  valid for a file or folder name; unfortunately, there are filesystems
2600     *  where this is not true.
2601     *
2602     *  @note   This method will not take care about the length of the returned
2603     *      String; this means the result to a call to this method may still be
2604     *      invalid as a file or folder name because it is too long.
2605     *
2606     *  @param  s   The input String, denoting a file or folder name -
2607     *      <i>not</i> a full path.
2608     *  @return The String without the characters that are invalid for a file
2609     *      name. This value will never be {@code null} or empty.
2610     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The input is {@code null}.
2611     *  @throws EmptyArgumentException  The input is the empty String.
2612     *  @throws ValidationException After stripping the invalid characters the
2613     *      return value would be empty.
2614     *
2615     *  @since 0.0.5
2616     */
2617    @SuppressWarnings( "SwitchStatementWithTooManyBranches" )
2618    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2619    public static final String stripToFilename( final CharSequence s ) throws ValidationException
2620    {
2621        final var len = requireNotEmptyArgument( s, "s" ).length();
2622        final var buffer = new StringBuilder( len );
2623        char c;
2624        ScanLoop: for( var i = 0; i < len; ++i )
2625        {
2626            c = s.charAt( i );
2627            Selector: switch( c )
2628            {
2629                case ':':
2630                case '\\':
2631                case '/':
2632                case ';':
2633                case '*':
2634                case '"':
2635                case '\'':
2636                case '@':
2637                case '|':
2638                case '?':
2639                case '<':
2640                case '>':
2641                    continue ScanLoop;
2642
2643                default:
2644                {
2645                    if( (c == ' ') || (!isISOControl( c ) && !isWhitespace( c )) )
2646                    {
2647                        buffer.append( c );
2648                    }
2649                    break Selector;
2650                }
2651            }   //  Selector:
2652        }   //  ScanLoop:
2653
2654        final var retValue = buffer.toString().trim();
2655        if( retValue.length() < 1 )
2656        {
2657            throw new ValidationException( format( "After stripping the invalid characters from '%1$s' there do not remain enough characters for a valid file name", s.toString() ) );
2658        }
2659
2660        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2661        return retValue;
2662    }   //  stripToFilename()
2663
2664    /**
2665     *  Strips HTML or XML comments from the given String.
2666     *
2667     *  @param  s   The HTML/XML string.
2668     *  @return The string without the comments.
2669     *
2670     *  @since 0.0.5
2671     */
2672    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2673    public static final String stripXMLComments( final CharSequence s )
2674    {
2675        final var matcher = m_CommentRemovalPattern.matcher( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ) );
2676        final var retValue = matcher.replaceAll( EMPTY_STRING );
2677
2678        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2679        return retValue;
2680    }   //  stripXMLComments()
2681
2682    /**
2683     *  Translates the given String to a String that will only contain
2684     *  printable ASCII characters; all other characters will be 'escaped' to
2685     *  the format &quot;&#92;uXXXX&quot;.
2686     *
2687     *  @param  s   The input string; may be {@code null}.
2688     *  @return The output string; {@code null} if the input string was
2689     *      already {@code null}.
2690     *
2691     *  @since 0.0.5
2692     *  @deprecated Use instead
2693     *      {@link CharSetUtils#convertUnicodeToASCII(java.text.Normalizer.Form, CharSequence)}
2694     *      with
2695     *      {@link java.text.Normalizer.Form#NFKC}
2696     *      as the first argument.
2697     */
2698    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2699    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2700    public static final String toUnicode( final CharSequence s )

2703    }   //  toUnicode()

2705    /**
2706     *  Changes the first letter of the given String tolower case as per
2707     *  {@link Character#toLowerCase(char)}.
2708     *  No other letters are changed. A {@code null} input String returns
2709     *  {@code null}.<br>
2710     *  <br>Samples:<pre><code>  StringUtils.uncapitalize( null ) = null;
2711     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;&quot;)     = &quot;&quot;;
2712     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;Cat&quot;)  = &quot;cat&quot;;
2713     *  StringUtils.uncapitalize(&quot;CAT&quot;)  = &quot;cAT&quot;;</code></pre>
2714     *  <br>Basically, this is the complementary method to
2715     *  {@link #capitalize(CharSequence)}.
2716     *  Use this method to normalise the name of bean attributes.
2717     *
2718     *  @param  s   The String to <i>uncapitalise</i>, may be {@code null}.
2719     *  @return The <i>uncapitalised</i> String, {@code null} if the argument
2720     *      was {@code null}.
2721     *  @see #capitalize(CharSequence)
2722     *
2723     *  @since 0.0.5
2724     *  @deprecated Use
2725     *      {@link #decapitalize(CharSequence)}
2726     *      instead.
2727     */
2728    @Deprecated( since = "0.1.0" )
2729    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2730    public static final String uncapitalize( final CharSequence s ) { return decapitalize( s ); }

2732    /**
2733     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2734     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes. Supports HTML
2735     *  5.0 entities.<br>
2736     *  <br>For example, the string
2737     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2738     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2739     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2740     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2741     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2742     *
2743     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2744     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2745     *      string was already {@code null}.
2746     *
2747     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2748     *  @see #escapeHTML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2749     *
2750     *  @since 0.0.5
2751     */
2752    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2753    public static final String unescapeHTML( final CharSequence str )
2754    {
2755        final var retValue = nonNull( str ) ? HTML50.unescape( str ) : null;
2756
2757        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2758        return retValue;
2759    }   //  unescapeHTML()

2761    /**
2762     *  Unescapes a string containing entity escapes to a string containing the
2763     *  actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes and writes it to
2764     *  the given
2765     *  {@link Appendable}.
2766     *  Supports HTML 4.0 entities.<br>
2767     *  <br>For example, the string
2768     *  &quot;&amp;lt;Fran&amp;ccedil;ais&amp;gt;&quot; will become
2769     *  &quot;&lt;Fran&ccedil;ais&gt;&quot;.<br>
2770     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2771     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2772     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2773     *
2774     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2775     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2776     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The appendable is {@code null}.
2777     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2778     *
2779     *  @see #escapeHTML(CharSequence)
2780     *
2781     *  @since 0.0.5
2782     */
2783    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2784    public static final void unescapeHTML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence str ) throws IOException
2785    {
2786        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2787
2788        if( nonNull( str ) ) HTML50.unescape( appendable, str );
2789    }   //  unescapeHTML()
2790
2791    /**
2792     *  Parses Strings in the format &quot;<code>&#92;uXXXX</code>&quot;,
2793     *  containing the textual representation of a single Unicode character, to
2794     *  the respective Unicode character. Some Unicode characters will be
2795     *  represented as <i>surrogate pairs</i> in Java, so the String that is
2796     *  returned by this method may contain more than one {@code char}.<br>
2797     *  <br>The input format for this method is used in Java source code
2798     *  Strings, in Java {@code .properties} files, in C/C++ source code, in
2799     *  JavaScript source, &hellip;
2800     *
2801     *  @param  s   The input String with the Unicode escape sequence.
2802     *  @return The Unicode character.
2803     *  @throws ValidationException The input is {@code null}, empty, or cannot
2804     *      be parsed as a unicode escape sequence.
2805     *
2806     *  @since 0.0.5
2807     *  @deprecated Use
2808     *      {@link CharSetUtils#unescapeUnicode(CharSequence)}
2809     *      instead.
2810     */
2811    @Deprecated( since ="0.1.0", forRemoval = true )
2812    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2813    public static final String unescapeUnicode( final CharSequence s )
2814    {
2815        return CharSetUtils.unescapeUnicode( s );
2816    }   //  unescapeUnicode()
2817
2818    /**
2819     *  Unescapes an XML string containing XML entity escapes to a string
2820     *  containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the
2821     *  escapes.<br>
2822     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2823     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2824     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2825     *
2826     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2827     *  @return A new unescaped {@code String}, {@code null} if the given
2828     *      string was already {@code null}.
2829     *
2830     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2831     *  @see #escapeXML(Appendable,CharSequence)
2832     *
2833     *  @since 0.0.5
2834     */
2835    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2836    public static final String unescapeXML( final CharSequence str )
2837    {
2838        final var retValue = nonNull( str ) ? XML.unescape( str ) : null;
2839
2840        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2841        return retValue;
2842    }   //  unescapeXML()
2843
2844    /**
2845     *  Unescapes an XML String containing XML entity escapes to a String
2846     *  containing the actual Unicode characters corresponding to the escapes
2847     *  and writes it to the given
2848     *  {@link Appendable}.<br>
2849     *  <br>If an entity is unrecognised, it is left alone, and inserted
2850     *  verbatim into the result string. e.g. &quot;&amp;gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;
2851     *  will become &quot;&gt;&amp;zzzz;x&quot;.
2852     *
2853     *  @param  appendable  The appendable receiving the unescaped string.
2854     *  @param  str The {@code String} to unescape, may be {@code null}.
2855     *  @throws NullArgumentException   The writer is {@code null}.
2856     *  @throws IOException An IOException occurred.
2857     *
2858     *  @see #escapeXML(CharSequence)
2859     *
2860     *  @since 0.0.5
2861     */
2862    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2863    public static final void unescapeXML( final Appendable appendable, final CharSequence str ) throws IOException
2864    {
2865        requireNonNullArgument( appendable, "appendable" );
2866
2867        if( nonNull( str ) ) XML.unescape( appendable, str );
2868    }   //  unescapeXML()
2869
2870    /**
2871     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given character. This will
2872     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2873     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2874     *
2875     *  @param  c   The character.
2876     *  @return The escape sequence.
2877     *
2878     *  @deprecated Use
2879     *      {@link CharSetUtils#escapeCharacter(char)}
2880     *      instead.
2881     *
2882     *  @since 0.0.5
2883     */
2884    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2885    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2886    public static final String unicodeEscape( final char c ) { return escapeCharacter( c ); }
2887
2888    /**
2889     *  Returns the Unicode escape sequence for the given code point. This will
2890     *  return &quot;&#92;u0075&quot; for the letter 'u', and
2891     *  &quot;&#92;u003c&quot; for the smaller-than sign '&lt;'.
2892     *
2893     *  @param  codePoint   The character.
2894     *  @return The escape sequence.
2895     *
2896     *  @deprecated Use
2897     *      {@link #escapeUnicode(int)}
2898     *      instead.
2899     *
2900     *  @since 0.0.5
2901     */
2902    @API( status = DEPRECATED, since = "0.0.5" )
2903    @Deprecated( forRemoval = true )
2904    public static final String unicodeEscape( final int codePoint ) { return escapeUnicode( codePoint ); }
2905
2906    /**
2907     *  Returns the given URL encoded String in its decoded form, using the
2908     *  UTF-8 character encoding.<br>
2909     *  <br>Internally, this method and
2910     *  {@link #urlEncode(CharSequence)}
2911     *  make use of the methods from
2912     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder}
2913     *  and
2914     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder}, respectively. The methods here were
2915     *  introduced to simplify the handling, as first only the UTF-8 encoding
2916     *  should be used - making the second argument for the methods
2917     *  {@link java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String) decode()}/
2918     *  {@link java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String) encode()}
2919     *  obsolete - and second, they could throw an
2920     *  {@link UnsupportedEncodingException} - although this should never occur
2921     *  when UTF-8 encoding is used.
2922     *
2923     *  @param  s   The input String.
2924     *  @return The decoded result.
2925     *
2926     *  @see java.net.URLDecoder#decode(String, String)
2927     *
2928     *  @since 0.0.5
2929     */
2930    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2931    public static final String urlDecode( final CharSequence s )
2932    {
2933        final var retValue = decode( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).toString(), UTF8 );
2934
2935        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2936        return retValue;
2937    }   //  urlDecode()
2938
2939    /**
2940     *  Returns the given String in its URL encoded form, using the
2941     *  UTF-8 character encoding.
2942     *
2943     *  @param  s   The input String.
2944     *  @return The URL encoded result.
2945     *
2946     *  @see java.net.URLEncoder#encode(String, String)
2947     *  @see #urlDecode(CharSequence)
2948     *
2949     *  @since 0.0.5
2950     */
2951    @API( status = STABLE, since = "0.0.5" )
2952    public static final String urlEncode( final CharSequence s )
2953    {
2954        final var retValue = encode( requireNonNullArgument( s, "s" ).toString(), UTF8 );
2955
2956        //---* Done *----------------------------------------------------------
2957        return retValue;
2958    }   //  urlEncode()
2959}
2960//  class StringUtils
